lines.text: Part fools!
lines.character: Benvolio - Nephew to Montgue and Friend to Romeo

lines.text: [Benvolio grabs his sword and walks in the fight. The soldiers in the streets continue to sword fight each others]
Put up your swords! Put up your swords!
lines.character: Benvolio - Nephew to Montgue and Friend to Romeo

lines.text: [Benvolio breaks up the fight and some soldiers stops fighting. Tybalt shows up]
What, art thou drawn among these heartless hinds? Turn thee, Benvolio, look upon thy death!
lines.character: Tybalt - Nephew to Lady Capulet

lines.text: I do but keep the peace. Put up thy sword. Or manage it to part these men with me.
lines.character: Benvolio - Nephew to Montgue and Friend to Romeo

lines.text: [Tybalt walks right up to Benvolio while holding his sword and talks right at his face]
Have at thee, coward!
lines.character: Tybalt - Nephew to Lady Capulet

lines.text: [Tybalt fights against Benvolio in a duel. The women scream. The soldiers continue to fight until Prince Escalus and his guards on horses come into the streets and the fighting stops]
Rebellious subjects, enemies to peace.
lines.character: Escalus - Prince of Verona

lines.text: [Prince Escalus waits until all the soldiers stop fighting in the streets]

Will they not hear? What, ho! Ye men! You beasts! On pain of torture, Throw your mistempered weapons to the ground. And hear the sentence of your moved prince. Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word, By thee, old Capulet, and Montague, Have thrice disturbed the quiet of our streets, If ever you disturb our streets again, Your lives shall pay the forfeit of the peace. For this time, all the rest depart away. You Capulet, shall go along with me. And, Montague, come you this afternoon. To know our further pleasure in this case, Once more, on pain of death, all men depart.
lines.character: Escalus - Prince of Verona

lines.text: Romeo. Romeo. Wherefore art thou Romeo?
lines.character: Juliet

lines.text:
[Samson bites his thumb at Abraham and spits on the ground]
I strike quickly being moved, than a dog of the house of Montague, moves me.
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text:
[the Montages walk behind Samson and Abraham puts his hand on his shoulder]
Do you bite your thumb at us sir?
lines.character: Abraham - Servant of the House of Montague

lines.text: I do bite my thumb sir.
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: Do you bite your thumb at us sir?
lines.character: Abraham - Servant of the House of Montague

lines.text: Is the law on our side if I say aye?
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: No.
lines.character: Gregory - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: No sir I do not bite my thumb at you sir, but I do bite my thumb sir.
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: [the men laugh and walks away, Samson and Gregory follows Abraham and walks up to him]
Do you quarrel sir?
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: Quarrel sir. No sir.
lines.character: Abraham - Servant of the House of Montague

lines.text: If you do sir, then I am for you. I serve as good a man as you.
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: No better, say that else.
lines.character: Abraham - Servant of the House of Montague

lines.text: Yes better!
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: You lie!
lines.character: Abraham - Servant of the House of Montague

lines.text: Draw if you be men!
lines.character: Samson - Servant of the House of Capulet

lines.text: [Then the Capulets and Montagues pull out their swords and they fight each other with swords in the streets. The women scream as the men are getting stabbed by swords]
